segment.source: This article describes how to use the CameraCaptureUI class to capture photos or videos using the camera UI built into Windows.
segment.target: This article describes how to use the CameraCaptureUI class to capture photos or videos using the camera UI built into Windows.

segment.source: Capture photos and video with CameraCaptureUI
segment.target: Capture photos and video with CameraCaptureUI

segment.source: Capture photos and video with CameraCaptureUI
segment.target: Capture photos and video with CameraCaptureUI

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: This article describes how to use the CameraCaptureUI class to capture photos or videos using the camera UI built into Windows.
segment.target: This article describes how to use the CameraCaptureUI class to capture photos or videos using the camera UI built into Windows.

segment.source: This feature is easy to use and allows your app to get a user-captured photo or video with just a few lines of code.
segment.target: This feature is easy to use and allows your app to get a user-captured photo or video with just a few lines of code.

segment.source: If your scenario requires more robust, low-level control of the capture operation, you should use the MediaCapture object and implement your own capture experience.
segment.target: If your scenario requires more robust, low-level control of the capture operation, you should use the MediaCapture object and implement your own capture experience.

segment.source: For more information, see Capture photos and video with MediaCapture.
segment.target: For more information, see Capture photos and video with MediaCapture.

segment.source: Capture a photo with CameraCaptureUI
segment.target: Capture a photo with CameraCaptureUI

segment.source: To use the camera capture UI, include the Windows.Media.Capture namespace in your project.
segment.target: To use the camera capture UI, include the Windows.Media.Capture namespace in your project.

segment.source: To do file operations with the returned image file, include Windows.Storage.
segment.target: To do file operations with the returned image file, include Windows.Storage.

segment.source: UsingCaptureUI
segment.target: UsingCaptureUI

segment.source: To capture a photo, create a new CameraCaptureUI object.
segment.target: To capture a photo, create a new CameraCaptureUI object.

segment.source: Using the object's PhotoSettings property you can specify properties for the returned photo such as the image format of the photo.
segment.target: Using the object's PhotoSettings property you can specify properties for the returned photo such as the image format of the photo.

segment.source: By default, the camera capture UI allows the user to crop the photo before it is returned, although this can be disabled with the AllowCropping property.
segment.target: By default, the camera capture UI allows the user to crop the photo before it is returned, although this can be disabled with the AllowCropping property.

segment.source: This example sets the CroppedSizeInPixels to request that the returned image be 200 x 200 in pixels.
segment.target: This example sets the CroppedSizeInPixels to request that the returned image be 200 x 200 in pixels.

segment.source: Note Imaging cropping in the CameraCaptureUI is not supported for devices in the Mobile device family.
segment.target: Note Imaging cropping in the CameraCaptureUI is not supported for devices in the Mobile device family.

segment.source: The value of the AllowCropping property is ignored when your app is running on these devices.
segment.target: The value of the AllowCropping property is ignored when your app is running on these devices.

segment.source: Call CaptureFileAsync and specify CameraCaptureUIMode.Photo to specify that a photo should be captured.
segment.target: Call CaptureFileAsync and specify CameraCaptureUIMode.Photo to specify that a photo should be captured.

segment.source: The method returns a StorageFile instance containing the image if the capture is successful.
segment.target: The method returns a StorageFile instance containing the image if the capture is successful.

segment.source: If the user cancels the capture, the returned object is null.
segment.target: If the user cancels the capture, the returned object is null.

segment.source: CapturePhoto
segment.target: CapturePhoto

segment.source: Once you have the StorageFile containing the captured photo, you can create a SoftwareBitmap object that can be used with several different Universal Windows app features.
segment.target: Once you have the StorageFile containing the captured photo, you can create a SoftwareBitmap object that can be used with several different Universal Windows app features.

segment.source: First you should include the Windows.Graphics.Imaging namespace in your project.
segment.target: First you should include the Windows.Graphics.Imaging namespace in your project.

segment.source: UsingSoftwareBitmap
segment.target: UsingSoftwareBitmap

segment.source: Call OpenAsync to get a stream from the image file.
segment.target: Call OpenAsync to get a stream from the image file.

segment.source: Call BitmapDecoder.CreateAsync to get a bitmap decoder for the stream.
segment.target: Call BitmapDecoder.CreateAsync to get a bitmap decoder for the stream.

segment.source: Then call GetSoftwareBitmap to get a SoftwareBitmap representation of the image.
segment.target: Then call GetSoftwareBitmap to get a SoftwareBitmap representation of the image.

segment.source: SoftwareBitmap
segment.target: SoftwareBitmap

segment.source: To display the image in your UI, declare an Image control in your XAML page.
segment.target: To display the image in your UI, declare an Image control in your XAML page.

segment.source: ImageControl
segment.target: ImageControl

segment.source: To use the software bitmap in your XAML page, include the using Windows.UI.Xaml.Media.Imaging namespace in your project.
segment.target: To use the software bitmap in your XAML page, include the using Windows.UI.Xaml.Media.Imaging namespace in your project.

segment.source: UsingSoftwareBitmapSource
segment.target: UsingSoftwareBitmapSource

segment.source: The Image control requires that the image source be in BGRA8 format with premultiplied alpha or no alpha, so call the static method SoftwareBitmap.Convert to create a new software bitmap with the desired format.
segment.target: The Image control requires that the image source be in BGRA8 format with premultiplied alpha or no alpha, so call the static method SoftwareBitmap.Convert to create a new software bitmap with the desired format.

segment.source: Next, create a new SoftwareBitmapSource object and call SetBitmapAsync to assign the software bitmap to the source.
segment.target: Next, create a new SoftwareBitmapSource object and call SetBitmapAsync to assign the software bitmap to the source.

segment.source: Finally, set the Image control's Source property to display the captured photo in the UI.
segment.target: Finally, set the Image control's Source property to display the captured photo in the UI.

segment.source: SetImageSource
segment.target: SetImageSource

segment.source: Capture a video with CameraCaptureUI
segment.target: Capture a video with CameraCaptureUI

segment.source: To capture a video, create a new CameraCaptureUI object.
segment.target: To capture a video, create a new CameraCaptureUI object.

segment.source: Using the object's VideoSettings property you can specify properties for the returned video such as the format of the video.
segment.target: Using the object's VideoSettings property you can specify properties for the returned video such as the format of the video.

segment.source: Call CaptureFileAsync and specify Video to specify that a video should be capture.
segment.target: Call CaptureFileAsync and specify Video to specify that a video should be capture.

segment.source: The method returns a StorageFile instance containing the video if the capture is successful.
segment.target: The method returns a StorageFile instance containing the video if the capture is successful.

segment.source: If the user cancels the capture, the returned object is null.
segment.target: If the user cancels the capture, the returned object is null.

segment.source: CaptureVideo
segment.target: CaptureVideo

segment.source: What you do with the captured video file depends on the scenario for your app.
segment.target: What you do with the captured video file depends on the scenario for your app.

segment.source: The rest of this article shows you how to quickly create a media composition from one or more captured videos and show it in your UI.
segment.target: The rest of this article shows you how to quickly create a media composition from one or more captured videos and show it in your UI.

segment.source: First, add a MediaElement control in which the video composition will be displayed to your XAML page.
segment.target: First, add a MediaElement control in which the video composition will be displayed to your XAML page.

segment.source: MediaElement
segment.target: MediaElement

segment.source: Add the Windows.Media.Editing and Windows.Media.Core namespaces to your project.
segment.target: Add the Windows.Media.Editing and Windows.Media.Core namespaces to your project.

segment.source: UsingMediaComposition
segment.target: UsingMediaComposition

segment.source: Declare member variables for a MediaComposition object and a MediaStreamSource that you want to stay in scope for the lifetime of the page.
segment.target: Declare member variables for a MediaComposition object and a MediaStreamSource that you want to stay in scope for the lifetime of the page.

segment.source: DeclareMediaComposition
segment.target: DeclareMediaComposition

segment.source: Once, before you capture any videos, you should create a new instance of the MediaComposition class.
segment.target: Once, before you capture any videos, you should create a new instance of the MediaComposition class.

segment.source: InitComposition
segment.target: InitComposition

segment.source: With the video file returned from the camera capture UI, create a new MediaClip by calling MediaClip.CreateFromFileAsync.
segment.target: With the video file returned from the camera capture UI, create a new MediaClip by calling MediaClip.CreateFromFileAsync.

segment.source: Add the media clip to the composition's Clips collection.
segment.target: Add the media clip to the composition's Clips collection.

segment.source: Call GeneratePreviewMediaStreamSource to create the MediaStreamSource object from the composition.
segment.target: Call GeneratePreviewMediaStreamSource to create the MediaStreamSource object from the composition.

segment.source: AddToComposition
segment.target: AddToComposition

segment.source: Finally, set the stream source to using the media element's SetMediaStreamSource method to show the composition in the UI.
segment.target: Finally, set the stream source to using the media element's SetMediaStreamSource method to show the composition in the UI.

segment.source: SetMediaElementSource
segment.target: SetMediaElementSource

segment.source: You can continue to capture video clips and add them to the composition.
segment.target: You can continue to capture video clips and add them to the composition.

segment.source: For more information on media compositions, see Media compositions and editing.
segment.target: For more information on media compositions, see Media compositions and editing.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
segment.target: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
